1120665753307496449.text: Researchers checked 34 billion insufficiently random Ethereum keys, and found that 732 of the associated addresses had already been emptied, likely by thieves. One of those thieves had amassed a fortune that was at one point worth $54 million.https://www.wired.com/story/blockchain-bandit-ethereum-weak-private-keys/ …

1115518992397918208.text: The makers of HBO’s “Chernobyl” call the accident one of the “the worst man-made catastrophes in history” — a remarkable statement given that past man-made catastrophes resulted in tens of millions of deaths whereas Chernobyl will result in, at most, 200.https://www.forbes.com/sites/michaelshellenberger/2019/02/21/stop-letting-your-cartoon-fears-of-nuclear-bombs-kill-the-planet/ …

1097034012537704450.text: Only big short-term hashrate changes or hashrates differences in the same algorithm used by more than one coin pose a potential security problem. Bitcoin hashrate wasn't less secure a few years ago than it is today, even though it was only 1/1,000th of what it is today.

1111034197869821952.text: Hayek: “I don’t believe we shall ever have a good money again before we take the thing out of the hands of government. That is, we can’t take them violently out of the hands of government. All we can do is by some sly roundabout way introduce something that they can’t stop.”

Building apps with https://www.scuttlebutt.nz  is orders of magnitude simpler than building conventional client-server apps, because it eliminates:
- Hosting
- Registration flow
- Login flow
- Password, email, 2FA
- DB maintenance
- Captchas
- Spam
- Terms of service
- Privacy policy

1006931729679044608.text: Proof-of-Work and Proof-of-Stake are **sybil control mechanisms**. PoS doesn't achieve consensus by itself. It has to be coupled with a protocol, such as PBFT, or Ben-Or, or Tendermint/Cosmos, or Avalanche, to make decisions.

It's bad enough that the word "crypto" has come to refer to cryptocurrency and not cryptography, but it's flat out wrong to say that Bitcoin uses "encryption".

Bitcoin transactions are signed and hashed but not encrypted. All privacy in Bitcoin is mere pseudonymity.

Tech buzzwords explained:
AI—regression
Big data—data
Blockchain—database
Algorithm—automated decision-making
Cloud—Internet
Crypto—cryptocurrency
Dark web—Onion service
Data science—statistics done by nonstatisticians
Disruption—competition
Viral—popular
IoT—malware-ready device
